Version control systems allow you to track changes to your code over time and revert to previous versions if necessary.

To create a new repository on a version control service, you will need to create an account with the service and follow the instructions provided. Once you have created a repository, you can clone it to your local machine, add code to it, commit your changes, and push them to the remote repository.
Pushing your code to the remote repository is a good way to keep your code safe and to share it with other developers. It is also a good way to collaborate on projects with other developers.

Creating a new branch allows you to isolate your changes from the main branch of the repository. This is useful when you are working on a new feature or bug fix, as it allows you to experiment without breaking the main branch.
To make changes to your code, open the code file in a code editor or IDE and make the changes you need. Save the file and test your code to make sure the changes work as expected.
Committing your changes regularly is a good way to keep track of your work and to create a history of your changes. It is also a good way to prepare for pushing your changes to a remote repository.

To create a pull request (PR), make your changes on a separate branch and push them to the remote repository. Then, create a new pull request and explain your changes in the description. Once the PR is approved, merge it into the main branch.

Reviewing pull requests is an important part of the software development process. By taking the time to review pull requests carefully, you can help to ensure that the code is high quality and that it meets the needs of the project.

Merging a pull request is the final step in the pull request workflow, and it results in the changes being made available to users. To merge a pull request, the developer who created it must first have all required approvals from other developers. Once the pull request is approved, the developer can merge it into the main branch.
Testing is the process of checking whether your code works as expected.

A unit test is a type of software test that verifies the functionality of a single unit of code, such as a function or class. Unit tests are typically written by developers and are run as part of the software development process.
Integration testing is the process of testing how different parts of your code work together.

Integration tests are important because they help to ensure that the different parts of a software system are working together as intended. Integration tests can also help to identify bugs that may not be found by unit tests.
Regression testing is the process of testing your code to make sure that changes you have made have not introduced any new bugs.
Regression tests are important because they help to ensure that the software system continues to work as intended after changes have been made.
Deployment is the process of making your code available to users.
Deploying code is making your code available to users. This typically involves uploading your code to a server and configuring it to run.

Monitoring code in production is the process of collecting and analyzing data about how your code is performing in a real-world environment. This data can be used to identify and fix bugs, improve performance, and ensure that your code is meeting the needs of your users.
Choose a project you\'re passionate about, set realistic goals, and break it down into smaller tasks. Don\'t be afraid to ask for help, and have fun!.
